page.title: Jini and Network Computing/Specifying a Codebase

revision.comment: [[Jini and Network Computing:Specifying a Codebase]] moved to [[Jini and Network Computing/Specifying a Codebase]]: [[Wikibooks:Naming policy]]
revision.text:
The classic specification of an RMI codebase is typically performed using the <tt>java.rmi.server.codebase</tt> system property on the command line starting the Java Virtual Machine. There are more powerful techniques that allow a single JVM to serve out remote objects with varied codebases. This mechanism is through the codebase annotation service provider interface available through the [[Jini and Network Computing:java.rmi.server.RMIClassLoaderSPI|RMIClassLoaderSPI]] abstract class.
One can simply subclass this class, providing the appropriate annotations that are appropriate for the classes in the getClassAnnotation(Class) call. A container could allow the user to specify a codebase that is associated with a classpath that it could associate with a specific ClassLoader. Then the implementation of RMIClassLoaderSPI would use the passed Class to find the appropriate ClassLoader that would then designate the codebase annotation that applied.
[[Category:Jini and Network Computing]]

revision.comment: [[Jini and Network Computing:java.rmi.server.RMIClassLoaderSPI]] moved to [[Jini and Network Computing/java.rmi.server.RMIClassLoaderSPI]]: [[Wikibooks:Naming policy]]
revision.text:
RMIClassLoaderSpi is the service provider interface for RMIClassLoader. It provides the ability for expanded control of the codebase annotation and unmarshalling control through the augmentation of the codebase.
[[Category:Jini and Network Computing]]

page.title: Jini and Network Computing/The jini-users mailing list

revision.comment: [[Jini and Network Computing:the jini-users mailing list]] moved to [[Jini and Network Computing/The jini-users mailing list]]: [[Wikibooks:Naming policy]]
revision.text:
This mailing list is a popular list for discussing both technical and community topics related to the Jini platform. There are a wide range of questions asked here and many repeating themes that have created a wide range of attempts at documenting as well as improving on the issues associated with Jini and distributed computing in general.
[[Category:Jini and Network Computing]]

page.title: Jini and Network Computing/The javaspaces-users mailing list

revision.comment: [[Jini and Network Computing:the javaspaces-users mailing list]] moved to [[Jini and Network Computing/The javaspaces-users mailing list]]: [[Wikibooks:Naming policy]]
revision.text:
This mailing list is used to cover Javaspaces specific issues. It has been the location of many interesting discussions about the basic interface to Javaspaces and the inability of that interface to deal with some very specific types of applications trying to force themselves into the Javaspaces mold.
[[Category:Jini and Network Computing]]

page.title: Jini and Network Computing/Consultancies with expertise in Jini and JavaSpaces

revision.comment: [[Jini and Network Computing:consultancies with expertise in Jini and JavaSpaces]] moved to [[Jini and Network Computing/Consultancies with expertise in Jini and JavaSpaces]]: [[Wikibooks:Naming policy]]
revision.text:
There are many visible signs of consulting opportunities for Jini and Javaspaces based SOA applications. One of the biggest items the community deals with is the rather strong silence from many commercial users. They view Jini as a strategic decision that they do not want to publically discuss and/or expose.
[[Category:Jini and Network Computing]]

page.title: Jini and Network Computing/Vendors selling Jini compatible tools or implementations

revision.comment: [[Jini and Network Computing:vendors selling Jini compatible tools or implementations]] moved to [[Jini and Network Computing/Vendors selling Jini compatible tools or implementations]]: [[Wikibooks:Naming policy]]
revision.text:
There a couple of well known Javaspaces implementations that are separate from the Outrigger service in the [[Jini and Network Computing:Jini Technology Starter Kit|Sun contributed implementation]].
  • The Blitz Javaspace by Dan Creswell is an Open Source implementation
  • GigaSpaces provides a commercial product that has a wide range of features including a Javaspaces API.
[[Category:Jini and Network Computing]]

page.title: Talk:How To Become A Good Student

revision.text:
{{rfd-survived}} This entire book makes absolutely no sense. No offense, but I think this entire book hurts people more than making them want to learn. Perhaps the author is not English-native, however, that is no excuse for the constant mis-use of the English language. Please edit/remove this book as soon as possible. <small>—''the preceding unsigned comment is by'' [[User:67.150.6.135|67.150.6.135]] ([[User talk:67.150.6.135|talk]] • [[Special:Contributions/67.150.6.135|contribs]]) 06:45, 18 January 2006 (UTC{{{3|}}})</small><!--Inserted with Template:Unsigned2-->
Excuse me, but your comment is awfully negative and undermines the spirit of this website, not to mention it is just very rude. I personally enjoyed this Wikibook very much and I think it could be very helpful to someone. Yes, it is obvious that English is not the first language of this author. I however, admire the courage it took for this person to write on a subject that is obviously very important to him, even though he is still struggling with the language. Maybe, instead of making negative comments, someone like you could actually help the author out and edit some of this Wikibook, so that it may be more clear and coherent for others readers. It is nay-sayers like you completely undermine the whole point of Wiki, and quite frankly, you make me sick. Good day. <small>—''the preceding unsigned comment is by'' [[User:12.47.73.242|12.47.73.242]] ([[User talk:12.47.73.242|talk]] • [[Special:Contributions/12.47.73.242|contribs]]) 20:58, 18 January 2006 (UTC{{{3|}}})</small><!--Inserted with Template:Unsigned2-->
== Message from Author ==
Well, not being harsh, it will take time for the completion of the book. So I'll slowly first put the main idea as to what to write. Then I'll try my best to make the English crystal clear as possible. You are most welcome to help. You can edit the module for now because it needs some attention. Then you can edit pages especially the ones which are provided by development stages mark. Note:- If you are adding a "Personal Note From Author" or adding your preface please assign a signature with timestamp to know who worte what. <small>—''the preceding unsigned comment is by'' [[User:Mastermind 007|Mastermind 007]] ([[User talk:Mastermind 007|talk]] • [[Special:Contributions/Mastermind 007|contribs]]) 10:41, 19 January 2006 (UTC{{{3|}}})</small><!--Inserted with Template:Unsigned2-->
== Regarding: How To Become A Good Student ==
Actually, the idea for the book is a very intriguing one at best. It is important that students know how to become better students. I wish that you would only provide constructive criticism. I thank the author for starting this. I will be looking for several links to organizations and books that further educate students. I speak from personal experience because at the moment, I am a student. I'm involved with several organizations that deal with leadership, changing paradigms, and other community work. I would be happy to help you in my spare time with all that needs to be done.--Helius 16:46, 21 January 2006 (UTC)
== A Work For Some ==
Hello! Thank you for sending discussions. I'm the one who came up with the idea of this book, so if you have queries please respond to me. I would be delighted if you can help especially in the English grammar of this book. Please try an effort also to make this book with a good look. Hope you understand the motto of this book! Have a good day and enjoy reading this Wikibook. --[[User:Mastermind 007|Mastermind 007]] 11:35, 22 January 2006 (UTC)
== A Reminder ==
This is an important reminder of ones who are currently reading this book. This book is mostly for students in order to enlighten them for their future. Since it's for students, I've kept the data as brief and easy as I can. So, if you're editing a section or a part of this book, try to keep it small so that it would be easy for you as well as for other students to understand. Hope you enjoy this book!!! --[[User:Mastermind 007|Mastermind 007]] 11:53, 22 January 2006 (UTC)
== A Simple Request ==
Hello! Everybody. I think I've worked on this book as much as I can and I think it deserves either a "Collaboration Of The Month" or "Book Of The Month" award. Please support this book as much as possible. Have a good time! --[[User:Mastermind 007|Mastermind 007]] 17:21, 22 January 2006 (UTC)
== Failed Editing Attempts ==
It was my intention to spend this entire editing session fixing grammatical and communicational errors within this book. I quickly realized, however, that it is, as an editor, an extremely difficult book to approach, due, in large part, to the plentiful usage of first person point-of-view, and the constant basis on the author's personal experiences. This circumstance makes it difficult to both refine grammar and to add new advice and/or content beyond the author's own contributions. This is quite a shame given the author's obviously kind-hearted intentions. That is to say, it is unfortunate that such a book as this should suffer because of communicational barriers.
If the author is still interested in producing and developing this book, I would recommend to them that they take a day to revamp the book from a [[w:The Seven Habits of Highly Successful People|7 Habits of Highly Effective Adults/Teens/Etc.]] style, to a more neutral POV manual of advice, so that it may be more easily approached by outside editors. My email address can be found here if the author would like to discuss this with me personally: [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:Emailuser/Mitglied_von_die_Elektronischenzyklop%C3%A4die_Schriftleitung Wikipedia Email Service] --[[User:24.175.54.43|24.175.54.43]] 06:32, 7 July 2006 (UTC)
== Major Revisions/Additions ==
D. I just wrote in a preface which described the importance and use of this page. I tried to explain the importance of this page as simply and as concisely as possible. If anyone can improve it or add additional information I would invite them to edit it.
I just spent a fair bit of time on each of the chapters (except the last one, which is only a single paragraph at the moment) and I am quite happy with how things turned out. Overall the thing is still simply too difficult to read, but I intend on fixing this soon. Also, despite having covered the very basics, we need to spend time getting some more useful content into each of the chapters. I think the chapter on management is the most important one at the moment.
''Chapter 1: Motivation'' is fine at the moment, but nothing too special. ''Chapter 2: Concentration on studies'' has been improved nicely, but once again will need work later. ''Chapter 3: Behaviour'' is almost useless at the moment... I really can't see some guy reading that chapter and getting anything out of it. However, I do see potential in it. ''Chapter 4: Management'' is where I feel we should focus our energy. Putting things like 'how to keep a good study plan' would be invaluable in this book. ''Chapter 5: Helping Others And Advising''... I seriously think this would be one of the things that should be put at the very end of the book, as the book is about helping ''yourself'', not others. But if this book was fairly developed, then I would welcome it.
Well I'll see what I can do, but I know this could be a very good book if we work on it. --[[User:Babij|Babij]] 08:31, 8 July 2006 (UTC)
Agreed. Needs major work before it can be considered complete. Plus - please get rid of the annoying and poorly designed logo at the top of the page. It's unnecessary.
I like this idea! thank you because you help mehow to bcome a good student.

Hi. I am a 2nd year bio-engineering major at the University of California, San Diego.
I enjoy tinkering with mechanics, such as bicycles, skateboards or otherwise.

== [[Guide to First Year Teaching]] == Yes, naming convention in this book is okay. Plese don't sign your name in book pages - authors should be mentioned once, in separate chapter (I see you already have one, that's fine). You can add nice navigation to your book - see [[Wikibooks:Template messages/Navigation]]. --[[User:Derbeth|Derbeth]] [[User talk:Derbeth|talk]] 07:43, 18 January 2006 (UTC) == [[Trouble With Mandy]] == I was poking through the [[Special:Lonelypages|ophaned pages]] and stumbled across [[Trouble With Mandy]]. I was about to put it up for [[WB:VFD|Votes for Deletion]] when I noticed it might belong to your [[Guide to First Year Teaching]]. You should probably have a look at it and see if it belongs to that book or some other you know about. --[[User:JMRyan|JMRyan]] 01:51, 1 February 2006 (UTC) == Your account will be renamed ==
Hello, The developer team at Wikimedia is making some changes to how accounts work, as part of our on-going efforts to provide new and better tools for our users like cross-wiki notifications. These changes will mean you have the same account name everywhere. This will let us give you new features that will help you edit and discuss better, and allow more flexible user permissions for tools. One of the side-effects of this is that user accounts will now have to be unique across all 900 Wikimedia wikis. See [[m:Special:MyLanguage/Single User Login finalisation announcement|the announcement]] for more information. Unfortunately, your account clashes with another account also called Acastro. To make sure that both of you can use all Wikimedia projects in future, we have reserved the name Acastro~enwikibooks that only you will have. If you like it, you don't have to do anything. If you do not like it, you can [[Special:GlobalRenameRequest|pick out a different name]]. Your account will still work as before, and you will be credited for all your edits made so far, but you will have to use the new account name when you log in. Sorry for the inconvenience. Yours,
[[m:User:Keegan (WMF)|Keegan Peterzell]]
Community Liaison, Wikimedia Foundation
22:55, 17 March 2015 (UTC) == Renamed ==

see the wiki starting at http://work.wikicities.com/wiki/Main_Page
[[Category:Open Culture]]
Please stop adding nonsense to Wikibooks. It is considered [[Wikibooks:Dealing with vandalism|vandalism]]. If you would like to experiment, use the [[Wikibooks:Sandbox|sandbox]]. Thank you.

==Introduction==
In the following we will provide some notes on numerical optimization algorithms. As there are [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimization_%28mathematics%29 numerous methods] out there, we will restrict ourselves to the so-called ''Gradient Methods''. There are basically two arguments why we consider this class as a natural starting point when thinking about numerical optimization algorithms. On the one hand, these methods are really workhorses in the field, so their frequent use in practice justifies their coverage here. On the other hand, this approach is highly intuitive in the sense that it somewhat follow naturally from the well-known [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stationary_point properties of optima]. In particular we will concentrate on three examples of this class: the ''Newtonian Method'', the ''Method of Steepest Descent'' and the class of ''Variable Metric Methods'', nesting amongst others the ''Quasi Newtonian Method''.
Before we start we will nevertheless stress that there does not seem to be a "one and only" algorithm but the performance of specific algorithms is always contingent on the specific problem to be solved. Therefore both experience and "trial-and-error" are very important in applied work. To clarify this point we will provide a couple of applications where the performance of different algorithms can be compared graphically. Furthermore a specific example on [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maximum_likelihood Maximum Likelihood Estimation] can be found at the end. Especially for statisticians and [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Econometrics econometricians] the Maximum Likelihood Estimator is probably the most important example of having to rely on numerical optimization algorithms in practice.
==Theoretical Motivation==
Any numerical optimization algorithm has solve the problem of finding "observable" properties of the function such that the computer program knows that a solution is reached. As we are dealing with problems of optimization two well-known results seem to be sensible starting points for such properties.
''If f is differentiable and <math>x^\star</math> is a (local) minimum, then''
<math> (1a) \quad Df(x^\star) = 0 </math>
''i.e. the Jacobian <math> D f(x) </math> is equal to zero''
and
''If f is twice differentiable and <math> x^\star </math> is a (local) minimum, then''
<math> (1b) \quad x^{T}D^2 f(x^\star)x \geq 0 </math>
''i.e. the Hessian <math> D^2 f(x) </math> is [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Positive-definite_matrix pos. semidefinite].''
In the following we will always denote the minimum by <math> x^\star </math>. Although these two conditions seem to represent statements that help in finding the optimum <math> x^\star </math>, there is the little catch that they give the implications of <math> x^\star </math> being an optimum for the function <math> f </math>. But for our purposes we would need the opposite implication, i.e. finally we want to arrive at a statement of the form: "If some condition <math> g(f(x^\star))</math> is true, then <math> x^\star </math> is a minimum". But the two conditions above are clearly not sufficient in achieving this (consider for example the case of <math> f(x) = x^3 </math>, with <math> Df(0) = D^2 f(0) = 0 </math> but <math> x^{\star} \neq 0 </math>). Hence we have to look at an entire neighborhood of <math> x^\star </math> as laid out in the following sufficient condition for detecting optima:
''If <math> Df(x^\star) = 0 </math> and <math> x^{T}D^2f(z)x \geq 0, \forall x \in \mathbb{R}^n </math> and <math> z \in \mathcal{B}(x^\star, \delta)</math>, then: <math>x^\star</math> is a local minimum.''
''Proof: For'' <math> x \in \mathcal{B}(x^\star, \delta) </math> ''let'' <math> z=x^\star + t(x-x^\star) \in \mathcal{B} </math>. ''The [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taylor%27s_theorem Taylor approximation] yields:'' <math> f(x) - f(x^\star) = 0 + \frac{1}{2}(x-x^\star)^{T}D^2 f(z)(x-x^\star) \geq 0 </math>, ''where'' <math> \mathcal{B}(x^\star, \delta)</math> ''denotes an open ball around'' <math> x^\star </math>, ''i.e.'' <math> \mathcal{B}(x^\star, \delta) = \{x : ||x - x^\star|| \leq \delta \} </math> ''for'' <math> \delta > 0 </math>.
In contrast to the two conditions above, this condition is sufficient for detecting optima - consider the two trivial examples
<math> f(x) = x^3 </math> with <math> Df(x^\star = 0) = 0 </math> but <math> x^{T}D^2f(z)x = 6 z x^2 \not\geq 0 \quad (e.g. \,\,z = -\frac{\delta}{2})</math>
and
<math>f(x) = x^4</math> with <math> Df(x^\star = 0) = 0</math> and <math>x^{T}D^2f(z)x = 12 z^2 x^2 \geq 0 \quad \forall z</math>.
Keeping this little caveat in mind we can now turn to the numerical optimization procedures.
== Numerical Solutions ==
All the following algorithms will rely on the following assumption:
''(A1) The set <math> N(f,f(x^{(0)}) = \{x \in \mathbb{R}^n | f(x) \leq f(x^{(0)})\}</math> is [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compact_space compact]''
where <math> x^{(0)} </math> is some given starting value for the algorithm. The significance of this assumption has to be seen in the ''Weierstrass Theorem'' which states that every compact set contains its ''[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supremum supremum]'' and its ''[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infimum infimum]''. So ''(A1)'' ensures that there is some solution in <math> N(f,f(x^{(0)}) </math>. And at this global minimum <math> x^\star </math> it of course holds true that <math> D(f(x^\star)) = 0 </math>. So - keeping the discussion above in mind - the optimization problem basically boils down to the question of solving set of equations <math> D(f(x^\star)) = 0 </math>.
=== The Direction of Descent ===
The problems with this approach are of course rather generically as <math> D(f(x^\star)) = 0 </math> does hold true for [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stationary_point maxima and saddle points] as well. Hence, good algorithms should ensure that both maxima and saddle points are ruled out as potential solutions. Maxima can be ruled out very easily by requiring <math> f(x^{(k+1)}) < f(x^{(k)}) </math> i.e. we restrict ourselves to a [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sequence sequence] <math> \{x^{(k)} \}_{k} </math> such that the function value decreases in every step. The question is of course if this is always possible. Fortunately it is. The basic insight why this is the case is the following. When constructing the mapping <math> x^{(k+1)} = \varphi(x^{(k)}) </math> (i.e. the rule how we get from <math>x^{(k)}</math> to <math>x^{(k+1)}</math>) we have two degrees of freedoms, namely
* the direction <math> d^{(k)} </math> and
* the step length <math>\sigma^{(k)}</math>.
Hence we can choose in which direction we want to move to arrive at <math>x^{(k+1)}</math> ''and'' how far this movement has to be. So if we choose <math>d^{(k)}</math> and <math>\sigma^{(k)}</math> in the "right way" we can effectively ensure that the function value decreases. The formal representation of this reasoning is provided in the following
''Lemma: If <math> d^{(k)} \in \mathbb{R}^n </math> and <math> Df(x)^{T}d^{(k)} < 0</math> then: <math>\exists \bar{\sigma} > 0</math> such that''
<math> f(x + \sigma^{(k)} d^{(k)}) < f(x) \quad \forall \sigma \in (0,\bar{\sigma}) </math>
''Proof: As <math>Df(x)^{T} d^{(k)} < 0</math> and <math>Df(x)^{T} d^{(k)} = \lim_{\sigma \rightarrow 0} \frac{f(x + \sigma^{(k)} d^{(k)}) - f(x)}{\sigma^{(k)}}</math>, it follows that <math>f(x + \sigma^{(k)} d^{(k)}) < f(x)</math> for <math>\sigma^{(k)}</math> small enough.''
=== The General Procedure of Descending Methods === A direction vector <math>d^{(k)}</math> that satisfies this condition is is called a ''Direction of Descent''. In practice this Lemma allows us to use the following procedure to numerically solve optimization problems.
1. Define the [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sequence sequence] <math> \{x^{(k)} \}_{k} </math> recursively via <math> x^{(k+1)} = x^{(k)} + \sigma^{(k)} d^{(k)}</math>
2. Choose the direction <math>d^{(k)}</math> from local information at the point <math>x^{(k)}</math>
3. Choose a step size <math>\sigma^{(k)}</math> that ensures [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convergent_series convergence] of the algorithm.
4. Stop the iteration if <math>|f(x^{(k+1)}) - f(x^{(k)})| < \epsilon</math> where <math>\epsilon > 0</math> is some chosen tolerance value for the minimum
This procedure already hints that the choice of <math>d^{(k)}</math> and <math>\sigma^{(k)}</math> are not separable, but rather dependent. Especially note that even if the method is a descending method (i.e. both <math>d^{(k)}</math> and <math>\sigma^{(k)}</math> are chosen according to ''Lemma 1'') the convergence to the minimum is not guaranteed. At a first glance this may seem a bit puzzling. If we found a sequence <math> \{x^{(k)} \}_{k} </math> such that the function value decreases at every step, one might think that at some stage, i.e. in the limit of ''k'' tending to infinity we should reach the solution. Why this is not the case can be seen from the following example borrowed from W. Alt (2002, p. 76).
====Example 1==== * Consider the following example which does not converge although it is clearly descending. Let the criterion function be given by <math>f(x) = x^2</math>, let the starting value be <math>x^{(0)} = 1</math>, consider a (constant) direction vector <math>d^{(k)}=-1</math> and choose a step width of <math>\sigma^{(k)} = (\frac{1}{2})^{k+2}</math>. Hence the recursive definition of the [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sequence sequence] <math>\{x^{(k)} \}_{k}</math> follows as
<math>(2) \quad x^{(k+1)} = x^{(k)} + (\frac{1}{2})^{k+2} (-1) = x^{(k-1)} - (\frac{1}{2})^{k+1} - (\frac{1}{2})^{k+2} = x^{(0)} - \sum_{j=0}^{k} (\frac{1}{2})^{j+2}. </math>
Note that <math> x^{(k)} > 0 \,\, \forall \,\, k</math> and hence <math> f(x^{(k+1)}) < f(x^{(k)}) \,\, \forall \,\,k</math>, so that it is clearly a descending method. Nevertheless we find that
<math>(3) \quad lim_{k \rightarrow \infty}x^{(k)} = lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} x^{(0)} - \sum_{j=0}^{k-1} (\frac{1}{2})^{j+2} = lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} 1 - \frac{1}{4}(\frac{1-(\frac{1}{2})^{k}}{\frac{1}{2}}) = lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{2} + (\frac{1}{2})^{k+1} = \frac{1}{2} \neq 0 = x^\star. </math>
The reason for this non-convergence has to be seen in the stepsize <math>\sigma^{(k)}</math> decreasing too fast. For large ''k'' the steps <math>x^{(k+1)} - x^{(k)}</math> get so small that convergence is precluded. Hence we have to link the stepsize to the direction of descend <math>d^{(k)}</math>.
=== Efficient Stepsizes === The obvious idea of such a linkage is to require that the actual descent is proportional to a first order approximation, i.e. to choose <math>\sigma^{(k)}</math> such that there is a constant <math>c_1 > 0</math> such that
<math> (4) \quad f(x^{(k)} + \sigma^{(k)}d^{(k)}) - f(x^{(k)}) \leq c_1 \sigma^{(k)} D(f(x^{(k)})) d^{(k)} < 0. </math>
Note that we still look only at descending directions, so that <math> Df(x^{(k)})^{T}d^{(k)} < 0 </math> as required in Lemma 1 above. Hence, the compactness of <math> N(f,f(x^{(k)})) </math> implies the [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convergent_series convergence] of the LHS and by (4)
<math> (5) \quad \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \sigma^{(k)} D(f(x^{(k)})) d^{(k)} = 0. </math>
Finally we want to choose a sequence <math> \{x^{(k)} \}_{k} </math> such that <math> \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty}D(f(x^{(k)})) = 0 </math> because that is exactly the necessary first order condition we want to solve. Under which conditions does (5) in fact imply <math> \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty}D(f(x^{(k)})) = 0 </math>? First of all the stepsize <math> \sigma^{(k)} </math> must not go to zero too quickly. That is exactly the case we had in the example above. Hence it seems sensible to bound the stepsize from below by requiring that
<math> (6) \quad \sigma^{(k)} \geq -c_{2} \frac{Df(x^{(k)})^{T}d^{(k)}}{|| d^{(k)}||^{2}} > 0 </math>
for some constant <math>c_2 > 0</math>. Substituting (6) into (5) finally yields
<math> (7) \quad f(x^{(k)} + \sigma^{(k)}d^{(k)}) - f(x^{(k)}) \leq -c (\frac{Df(x^{(k)})^{T}d^{(k)}}{|| d^{(k)}||})^{2}, \quad c = c_1 c_2 </math>
where again the [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compact_space compactness] of <math> N(f,f(x^{(k)})) </math> ensures the [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convergent_series convergence] of the LHS and hence
<math> (8) \quad lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} -c (\frac{Df(x^{(k)})^{T}d^{(k)}}{|| d^{(k)}||})^{2} = lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \frac{Df(x^{(k)})^{T}d^{(k)}}{|| d^{(k)}||} = 0 </math>
Stepsizes that satisfy (4) and (6) are called ''efficient stepsizes'' and will be denoted by <math>\sigma_{E}^{(k)}</math>. The importance of condition (6) is illustrated in the following continuation of Example 1.
====Example 1 (continued)==== * Note that it is exactly the failure of (6) that induced Example 1 not to converge. Substituting the stepsize of the example into (6) yields
<math>(6.1) \quad \sigma^{(k)} = (\frac{1}{2})^{(k+2)} \geq -c_{2} \frac{2x^{(k)}(-1)}{1} = c_{2}\cdot2(\frac{1}{2}+(\frac{1}{2})^{k+1}) \Leftrightarrow \frac{1}{4(1+2^{(k)})} \geq c_{2} > 0 </math>
so there is ''no'' constant <math>c_{2} > 0</math> satisfying this inequality for all ''k'' as required in (6). Hence the stepsize is not bounded from below and decreases too fast. To really acknowledge the importance of (6), let us change the example a bit and assume that <math>\sigma^{(k)} = (\frac{1}{2})^{k+1}</math>. Then we find that
<math>(6.2) \quad lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} x^{(k+1)} = lim_{k \rightarrow \infty}x^{(0)} - \frac{1}{2}\sum_{i}(\frac{1}{2})^{i} = lim_{k \rightarrow \infty}(\frac{1}{2})^{k+1} = 0 = x^\star, </math>
i.e. [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convergent_series convergence] actually does take place. Furthermore recognize that this example actually does satisfy condition (6) as
<math>(6.3) \quad \sigma^{(k)} = (\frac{1}{2})^{(k+1)} \geq -c_{2} \frac{2x^{(k)}(-1)}{1} = c_{2}\cdot 2(\frac{1}{2})^{k} \Leftrightarrow \frac{1}{4} \geq c_{2} >0. </math>
=== Choosing the Direction ''d'' ===
We have already argued that the choice of <math>\sigma^{(k)}</math> and <math>d^{(k)}</math> is intertwined. Hence the choice of the "right" <math>d^{(k)}</math> is always contingent on the respective stepsize <math>\sigma^{(k)}</math>. So what does "right" mean in this context? Above we showed in equation (8) that choosing an ''efficient stepsize'' implied
<math> (8') \quad lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} -c (\frac{Df(x^{(k)})^{T}d^{(k)}}{|| d^{(k)}||})^{2} = lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \frac{Df(x^{(k)})^{T}d^{(k)}}{|| d^{(k)}||} = 0.</math>
The "right" direction vector will therefore guarantee that (8') implies that
<math> (9) \quad lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} Df(x^{(k)}) = 0</math>
as (9) is the condition for the chosen sequence <math> \{x^{(k)} \}_{k} </math> to converge. So let us explore what directions could be chosen to yield (9). Assume that the stepsize <math>\sigma_{k}</math> is ''efficient'' and define
<math>(10) \quad \beta^{(k)} = \frac{Df(x^{(k)})^{T}d^{(k)}}{|| Df(x^{(k)})|| ||d^{(k)}||} \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad \beta^{(k)}|| Df(x^{(k)})|| = \frac{Df(x^{(k)})^{T}d^{(k)}}{|| d^{(k)}||} </math>
By (8') and (10) we know that
<math>(11) \quad lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \beta^{(k)}|| Df(x^{(k)})|| = 0. </math>
So if we bound <math>\beta^{(k)}</math> from below (i.e. <math>\beta^{(k)} \leq - \delta < 0</math>), (11) implies that
<math>(12) \quad lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \beta^{(k)}|| Df(x^{(k)})|| = lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} || Df(x^{(k)})|| = lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} Df(x^{(k)}) = 0, </math>
where (12) gives just the condition of the sequence <math> \{x^{(k)} \}_{k} </math> converging to the solution <math>x^{\star}</math>. As (10) defines the direction vector <math> d^{(k)} </math> implicitly by <math> \beta^{(k)} </math>, the requirements on <math> \beta^{(k)} </math> translate directly into requirements on <math> d^{(k)} </math>.
=== Why Gradient Methods? ===
When considering the conditions on <math> \beta^{(k)} </math> it is clear where the term ''Gradient Methods'' originates from. With <math> \beta^{(k)} </math> given by
<math> \beta_{k} = \frac{D(f(x)) d^{(k)}}{|| Df(x^{(k)}) || || d^{(k)} ||} = cos(Df(x^{(k)}),d^{(k)}) </math>
we have the following result
''Given that'' <math>\sigma^{(k)}</math> ''was chosen efficiently and'' <math>d^{(k)}</math> ''satisfies''
<math>(13) \quad cos(Df(x^{(k)}),d^{(k)}) = \beta_{k} \leq - \delta < 0 </math>
''we have''
<math>(14) \quad lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} Df(x^{(k)}) \rightarrow 0 </math>
''Hence: Convergence takes place if the angle between the negative gradient at'' <math>x^{(k)}</math> ''and the direction'' <math>d^{(k)}</math> ''is consistently smaller than the right angle. Methods relying on'' <math>d^{(k)}</math> ''satisfying (13) are called Gradient Methods.''
In other words: As long as one is not moving [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orthogonal orthogonal] to the gradient and if the stepsize is chosen efficiently, ''Gradient Methods'' guarantee convergence to the solution <math>x^{\star}</math>.
=== Some Specific Algorithms in the Class of Gradient Methods=== Let us now explore three specific algorithms of this class that differ in their respective choice of <math>d^{(k)}</math>. ==== The Newtonian Method ==== The [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newton_method ''Newtonian Method''] is by far the most popular method in the field. It is a well known method to solve for the [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Root_%28mathematics%29 roots] of all types of equations and hence can be easily applied to optimization problems as well. The main idea of the Newtonian method is to linearize the system of equations to arrive at
<math>(15) \quad g(x) = g(\hat{x}) + Dg(\hat{x})^{T}(x-\hat{x}) = 0. </math>
(15) can easily be solved for ''x'' as the solution is just given by (assuming <math>Dg(\hat{x})^{T} </math> to be [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Singular_matrix non-singular])
<math>(16) \quad x = \hat{x} - [Dg(\hat{x})^{T}]^{-1}g(\hat{x}). </math>
For our purposes we just choose <math>g(x)</math> to be the gradient <math>Df(x)</math> and arrive at
<math> (17) \quad d_{N}^{(k)} = x^{(k+1)} - x^{(k)} = - [D^2f(x^{(k)})]^{-1}Df(x^{(k)}) </math>
where <math> d_{N}^{(k)} </math> is the so-called ''Newtonian Direction''.
===== Properties of the Newtonian Method =====
Analyzing (17) elicits the main properties of the Newtonian method:
* If <math>D^2f(x^{(k)})</math> is [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Positive-definite_matrix positive definite], <math>d_{N}^{k}</math> is a direction of descent in the sense of ''Lemma 1''.
* The ''Newtonian Method'' uses local information of the first ''and'' second derivative to calculate <math>d_{N}^{k}</math>.
* As
<math> (18) \quad x^{(k+1)} = x^{(k)} + d_{N}^{(k)} </math>
the ''Newtonian Method'' uses a fixed stepsize of <math> \sigma^{(k)} = 1 </math>. Hence the Newtonian method is ''not'' necessarily a descending method in the sense of ''Lemma 1''. The reason is that the fixed stepsize <math> \sigma^{(k)} = 1 </math> might be larger than the critical stepsize <math> \bar{\sigma_{k}} </math> given in ''Lemma 1''. Below we provide the Rosenbrock function as an example where the ''Newtonian Method'' is not descending.
* The Method can be time-consuming as calculating <math> [D^2f(x^{(k)})]^{-1} </math> for every step ''k'' can be cumbersome. In applied work one could think about approximations. One could for example update the Hessian only every ''s''th step or one could rely on ''local approximations''. This is known as the ''Quasi-Newtonian-Method'' and will be discussed in the section about ''Variable Metric Methods''.
* To ensure the method to be decreasing one could use an efficient stepsize <math> \sigma_{E}^{(k)} </math> and set
<math>(19) \quad x^{(k+1)} = x^{(k)} - \sigma_{E}^{(k)}d_{N}^{(k)} = x^{(k)} - \sigma_{E}^{(k)} [D^2 f(x^{k})]^{-1} Df(x^{(k)}) </math>
==== Method of Steepest Descent ==== Another frequently used method is the [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steepest_descent ''Method of Steepest Descent'']. The idea of this method is to choose the direction <math>d^{(k)}</math> so that the decrease in the function value ''f'' is maximal. Although this procedure seems at a first glance very sensible, it suffers from the fact that it uses effectively less information than the ''Newtonian Method'' by ignoring the Hessian's information about the curvature of the function. Especially in the applications below we will see a couple of examples of this problem.
The direction vector of the ''Method of Steepest Descent'' is given by
<math> (20) \quad d_{SD}^{(k)} = argmax_{d : ||d|| = r} \{-Df(x^{(k)})^{T}d \} = argmin_{d : ||d|| = r} \{Df(x^{(k)})^{T}d \} = -r \frac{Df(x)}{|| Df(x) ||} </math>
''Proof: By the [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cauchy-Schwartz_inequality Cauchy-Schwartz Inequality] it follows that''
<math> (21) \quad \frac{Df(x)^{T}d}{|| Df(x) || ||d||} \geq -1 \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad Df(x)^{T}d \geq -r || Df(x) ||. </math>
''Obviously (21) holds with equality for'' <math>d^{(k)} = d_{SD}^{(k)}</math> ''given in (20).''
Note especially that for <math>r = || Df(x) ||</math> we have <math>d_{SD}^{(k)} = - Df(x^{(k)})</math>, i.e. we just "walk" in the direction of the negative gradient. In contrast to the ''Newtonian Method'' the ''Method of Steepest Descent'' does not use a fixed stepsize but chooses an efficient stepsize <math>\sigma_{E}^{(k)}</math>. Hence the ''Method of Steepest Descent'' defines the sequence <math> \{x^{(k)} \}_{k} </math> by
<math> (22) \quad x^{(k+1)} = x^{(k)} + \sigma_{E}^{(k)} d_{SD}^{(k)}, </math>
where <math>\sigma_{E}^{(k)}</math> is an efficient stepsize and <math>d_{SD}^{(k)}</math> the Direction of Steepest Descent given in (20).
===== Properties of the Method of Steepest Descent ===== * With <math>d_{SD}^{(k)} = -r \frac{Df(x)}{|| Df(x)||}</math> the Method of Steepest Descent defines a direction of descent in the sense of ''Lemma 1'', as
<math>Df(x)^{T}d_{SD}^{(k)} = Df(x)^{T}(-r \frac{Df(x)}{|| Df(x)||}) = - \frac{r}{|| Df(x)||}Df(x)^{T}Df(x) < 0. </math>
* The ''Method of Steepest Descent'' is only locally sensible as it ignores second order information.
* Especially when the criterion function is flat (i.e. the solution <math>x^\star</math> lies in a "valley") the sequence defined by the Method of Steepest Descent fluctuates wildly (see the applications below, especially the example of the Rosenbrock function).
* As it does not need the Hessian, calculation and implementation of the ''Method of Steepest Descent'' is easy and fast.
==== Variable Metric Methods ==== A more general approach than both the ''Newtonian Method'' and the ''Method of Steepest Descent'' is the class of ''Variable Metric Methods''. Methods in this class rely on the updating formula
<math> (23) \quad x^{k+1} = x^{k} - \sigma_{E}^{(k)} [A^{k}]^{-1} Df(x^{k}). </math>
If <math>A^{k}</math> is a [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetric_matrix symmetric] and [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Positive-definite_matrix positive definite] matrix, (23) defines a descending method as <math>[A^{k}]^{-1}</math> is positive definite if and only if <math>A^{k}</math> is positive definite as well. To see this: just consider the [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spectral_decomposition spectral decomposition]
<math> (24) \quad A^{k} = \Gamma \Lambda \Gamma^{T} </math>
where <math>\Gamma</math> and <math>\Lambda</math> are the matrices with [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eigenvectors eigenvectors] and [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eigenvectors eigenvalues] respectively. If <math> A^{k}</math> is positive definite, all eigenvalues <math>\lambda_{i}</math> are strictly positive. Hence their inverse <math>\lambda_{i}^{-1}</math> are positive as well, so that <math>[A^{k}]^{-1} = \Gamma \Lambda^{-1} \Gamma^{T}</math> is clearly positive definite. But then, substitution of <math>d^{(k)} = [A^{k}]^{-1} Df(x^{k})</math> yields
<math> (25) \quad Df(x^{k})^{T}d^{(k)} = -Df(x^{k})^{T}[A^{k}]^{-1}Df(x^{k}) \equiv - v^{T} [A^{k}]^{-1} v \leq 0, </math>
i.e. the method is indeed descending. Up to now we have not specified the matrix <math>A^{k}</math>, but is easily seen that for two specific choices, the ''Variable Metric Method'' just coincides with the ''Method of Steepest Descent'' and the ''Newtonian Method'' respectively.
* For <math>A^{k} = \mathcal{I}</math> (with <math>\mathcal{I}</math> being the [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Identity_matrix identity matrix]) it follows that
<math> (22') \quad x^{k+1} = x^{k} - \sigma_{E}^{(k)} Df(x^{k})</math>
which is just the ''Method of Steepest Descent''.
* For <math>A^{k} = D^{2}f(x^{k})</math> it follows that
<math> (19') \quad x^{k+1} = x^{k} - \sigma_{E}^{(k)} [D^{2}f(x^{k})]^{-1}Df(x^{k})</math>
which is just the ''Newtonian Method'' using a stepsize <math>\sigma_{E}^{(k)}</math>.
===== The Quasi Newtonian Method ===== A further natural candidate for a ''Variable Metric Method'' is the ''Quasi Newtonian Method''. In contrast to the standard ''Newtonian Method'' it uses an efficient stepsize so that it is a descending method and in contrast to the ''Method of Steepest Descent'' it does not fully ignore the local information about the curvature of the function. Hence the ''Quasi Newtonian Method'' is defined by the two requirements on the matrix <math>A^{k}</math>:
* <math>A^{k}</math> should approximate the Hessian <math>D^{2}f(x^{k})</math> to make use of the information about the curvature and
* the update <math>A^{k} \rightarrow A^{k+1}</math> should be easy so that the algorithm is still relatively fast (even in high dimensions).
To ensure the first requirement, <math>A^{k+1}</math> should satisfy the so-called ''Quasi-Newtonian-Equation''
<math> (26) \quad A^{k+1}(x^{(k+1)} - x^{(k)}) = Df(x^{(k+1)})-Df(x^{(k)}) </math>
as all <math>A^{k}</math> satisfying (26) reflect information about the Hessian. To see this, consider the function <math>g(x)</math> defined as
<math> (27) \quad g(x) = f(x^{k+1})+Df(x^{k+1})^{T}(x - x^{k+1})+\frac{1}{2}(x-x^{k+1})^{T}A^{k+1}(x - x^{k+1}). </math>
Then it is obvious that <math>g(x^{k+1}) = f(x^{k+1})</math> and <math>Dg(x^{k+1}) = Df(x^{k+1})</math>. So <math>g(x)</math> and <math>f(x)</math> are reasonably similar in the neighborhood of <math>x^{(k+1)}</math>. In order to ensure that <math>g(x)</math> is also a good approximation at <math>x^{(k)}</math>, we want to choose <math>A^{k+1} </math> such that the gradients at <math>x^{(k)}</math> are identical. With
<math>(28) \quad Dg(x^{k}) = Df(x^{k+1}) - A^{k+1} (x^{k+1} - x^{k})</math>
it is clear that <math>Dg(x^{k}) = Df(x^{k})</math> if <math> A^{k+1}</math> satisfies the ''Quasi Newtonian Equation'' given in (26). But then it follows that
<math> (29) \quad A^{k+1} (x^{k+1} - x^{k}) = Df(x^{k+1}) - Dg(x^{k}) = Df(x^{k+1}) - Df(x^{k}) = D^2 f(\lambda x^{(k)} + (1-\lambda)x^{(k+1)})(x^{k+1} - x^{k}). </math>
Hence as long as <math>x^{(k+1)}</math> and <math>x^{(k)}</math> are not too far apart, <math>A^{k+1}</math> satisfying (26) is a good approximation of <math>D^2 f(x^{(k)})</math>.
Let us now come to the second requirement that the update of the <math>A^{k}</math> should be easy. One specific algorithm to do so is the so-called [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BFGS_method ''BFGS-Algorithm'']. The main merit of this algorithm is the fact that it uses only the already calculated elements <math>\{x^{(k)}\}_{k}</math> and <math>\{Df(x^{(k)})\}_{k}</math> to construct the update <math>A^{(k+1)}</math>. Hence no new entities have to be calculated but one has only to keep track of the ''x''-sequence and sequence of gradients. As a starting point for the BFGS-Algorithm one can provide any positive definite matrix (e.g. the identity matrix or the Hessian at <math>x^{(0)}</math>). The ''BFGS-Updating-Formula'' is then given by
<math> (30) \quad A^{k} = A^{k-1} - \frac{(A^{k-1})^{T}\gamma_{k-1}^{T}\gamma_{k-1}A^{k-1}}{\gamma_{k-1}^{T}A^{k-1}\gamma_{k-1}} + \frac{\Delta_{k-1}\Delta_{k-1}^{T}}{\Delta_{k-1}^{T}\gamma_{k-1}} </math>
where <math>\Delta_{k-1} = Df(x^{(k)}) - Df(x^{(k-1)})</math> and <math>\gamma_{k-1} = x^{(k)} - x^{(k-1)}</math>. Furthermore (30) ensures that all <math>A^{k}</math> are positive definite as required by ''Variable Metric Methods'' to be descending.
===== Properties of the Quasi Newtonian Method ===== * It uses second order information about the curvature of <math>f(x)</math> as the matrices <math>A^{k}</math> are related to the Hessian <math>D^{2}f(x)</math>.
* Nevertheless it ensures easy and fast updating (e.g. by the BFGS-Algorithm) so that it is faster than the standard Newtonian Method.
* It is a descending method as <math>A^{k}</math> are positive definite.
* It is relatively easy to implement as the BFGS-Algorithm is available in most numerical or statistical software packages.
== Applications ==
To compare the methods and to illustrate the differences between the algorithms we will now evaluate the performance of the ''Steepest Descent Method'', the standard ''Newtonian Method'' and the ''Quasi Newtonian Method'' with an efficient stepsize. We use two classical functions in this field, namely the Himmelblau and the Rosenbrock function.
=== Application I: The Himmelblau Function === The Himmelblau function is given by
<math> (31) \quad f(x,y) = (x^2 + y - 11)^2 + (x + y^2 - 7)^2 </math>
This fourth order polynomial has four minima, four saddle points and one maximum so there are enough possibilities for the algorithms to fail. In the following pictures we display the [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contour_line contour plot] and the 3D plot of the function for different starting values.
In Figure 1 we display the function and the paths of all three methods at a starting value of <math>(2, -4)</math>. Obviously the three methods do not find the same minimum. The reason is of course the different direction vector of the ''Method of Steepest Descent'' - by ignoring the information about the curvature it chooses a totally different direction than the two ''Newtonian Methods'' (see especially the right panel of Figure 1).
[[Image:Himmelblaufunction1.jpg|center|thumb|550px|Figure 1: The two Newton Methods converge to the same, the Method of Steepest Descent to a different minimum.]]
Consider now the starting value <math>(4.5, -0.5)</math>, displayed in Figure 2. The most important thing is of course that now ''all'' methods find different solutions. That the ''Method of Steepest Descent'' finds a different solution than the two ''Newtonian Methods'' is again not that surprising. But that the two ''Newtonian Methods'' converge to different solution shows the significance of the stepsize <math>\sigma</math>. With the ''Quasi-Newtonian Method'' choosing an efficient stepsize in the first iteration, both methods have different stepsizes ''and'' direction vectors for all iterations after the first one. And as seen in the picture: the consequence may be quite significant.
[[Image:Himmelblau no2.JPG|center|thumb|550px|Figure 2: Even all methods find different solutions.]]
=== Application II: The Rosenbrock Function ===
The Rosenbrock function is given by
<math> (32) \quad f(x,y) = 100(y - x^2)^2 + (1-x)^2 \ </math>
Although this function has only one minimum it is an interesting function for optimization problems. The reason is the very flat valley of this U-shaped function (see the right panels of Figures 3 and 4). Especially for [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Econometrics econometricians] this function may be interesting because in the case of Maximum Likelihood estimation flat criterion functions occur quite frequently. Hence the results displayed in Figures 3 and 4 below seem to be rather generic for functions sharing this problem.
My experience when working with this function and the algorithms I employed is that Figure 3 (given a starting value of <math>(2,-5)</math>) seems to be quite characteristic. In contrast to the Himmelblau function above, all algorithms found the same solution and given that there is only one minimum this could be expected. More important is the path the different methods choose as is reflects the different properties of the respective methods. It is seen that the ''Method of Steepest Descent'' fluctuates rather wildly. This is due to the fact that it does not use information about the curvature but rather jumps back and forth between the "hills" adjoining the valley. The two Newtonian Methods choose a more direct path as they use the second order information. The main difference between the two Newtonian Methods is of course the stepsize. Figure 3 shows that the ''Quasi Newtonian Method'' uses very small stepsizes when working itself through the valley. In contrast, the stepsize of the ''Newtonian Method'' is fixed so that it jumps directly in the direction of the solution. Although one might conclude that this is a disadvantage of the ''Quasi Newtonian Method'', note of course that in general these smaller stepsizes come with benefit of a higher stability, i.e. the algorithm is less likely to jump to a different solution. This can be seen in Figure 4.
[[Image:Rosenbrockfunction1.jpg|center|thumb|550px|Figure 3: All methods find the same solution, but the Method of Steepest Descent fluctuates heavily.]]
Figure 4, which considers a starting value of <math>(-2,-2)</math>, shows the main problem of the ''Newtonian Method'' using a fixed stepsize - the method might "overshoot" in that it is not descending. In the first step, the ''Newtonian Method'' (displayed as the purple line in the figure) jumps out of the valley to only bounce back in the next iteration. In this case convergence to the minimum still occurs as the gradient at each side points towards the single valley in the center, but one can easily imagine functions where this is not the case. The reason of this jump are the second derivatives which are very small so that the step <math>[Df(x^{(k)})]^{-1} Df(x^{(k)}))</math> gets very large due to the inverse of the Hessian. In my experience I would therefore recommend to use efficient stepsizes to have more control over the paths the respective Method chooses.
[[Image:Rosenbrockfunction2.jpg|center|thumb|550px|Figure 2: Overshooting of the Newtonian Method due to the fixed stepsize.]]
=== Application III: Maximum Likelihood Estimation ===
For econometricians and statisticians the [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maximum_likelihood Maximum Likelihood Estimator] is probably the most important application of numerical optimization algorithms. Therefore we will briefly show how the estimation procedure fits in the framework developed above.
As usual let
<math>(33) \quad f(Y | X; \theta) </math>
be the [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conditional_distribution conditional density] of <math>Y</math> given <math>X</math> with parameter <math>\theta</math> and
<math>(34) \quad l(\theta; Y | X) </math>
the [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Likelihood_function conditional likelihood function] for the parameter <math> \theta </math>
If we assume the data to be [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iid independently, identically distributed (iid)] then the sample log-likelihood follows as
<math>(35) \quad \mathcal{L}(\theta; Y_{1}, ..., Y_{N}) = \sum_{i}^{N} \mathcal{L}(\theta; Y_{i}) = \sum_{i}^{N} log(l(\theta; Y_{i})). </math>
Maximum Likelihood estimation therefore boils down to maximize (35) with respect to the parameter <math> \theta </math>. If we for simplicity just decide to use the ''Newtonian Method'' to solve that problem, the sequence <math> \{ \theta^{(k)} \}_{k} </math> is recursively defined by
<math>(36) \quad D_{\theta}\mathcal{L}(\theta^{(k+1)}) = D_{\theta}\mathcal{L}(\theta^{(k)}) + D_{\theta \theta}\mathcal{L}(\theta^{(k)})(\theta^{(k+1)} -\theta^{(k)}) = 0 \Leftrightarrow \theta^{(k+1)} = \theta^{(k)} - [D_{\theta \theta}\mathcal{L}(\theta^{(k)})]^{-1}D_{\theta}\mathcal{L}(\theta^{(k)}) </math>
where <math>D_{\theta}\mathcal{L}</math> and <math>D_{\theta \theta}\mathcal{L}</math> denotes the first and second derivative with respect to the parameter vector <math>\theta</math> and <math> [D_{\theta \theta} \mathcal{L}(\theta^{(k)})]^{-1}D_{\theta} \mathcal{L}(\theta^{(k)})</math> defines the ''Newtonian Direction'' given in (17). As Maximum Likelihood estimation always assumes that the conditional density (i.e. the distribution of the error term) is known up to the parameter <math>\theta</math>, the methods described above can readily be applied.
==== A Concrete Example of Maximum Likelihood Estimation ====
Assume a simple linear model
<math> (37a) \quad Y_{i} = \beta_{1} + \beta_{x} X_{i} + U_{i} </math>
with <math>\theta = (\beta_{1}, \beta_{2})'</math>. The conditional distribution ''Y'' is then determined by the one of ''U'', i.e.
<math> (37b) \quad p(Y_{i} - \beta_{1} - \beta_{x} X_{i}) \equiv p_{\mid X_{i}}(Y_{i}) = p(U_{i}), </math>
where <math>p</math> denotes the [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Density_function density function]. Generally, there is no closed form solution of maximizing (35) (at least if ''U'' does not happen to be [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Normal_distribution normally distributed]), so that numerical methods have to be employed. Hence assume that ''U'' follows [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Student%27s_t-distribution Student's t-distribution] with ''m'' [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Degrees_of_freedom_%28statistics%29 degrees of freedom] so that (35) is given by
<math> (38) \quad \mathcal{L}(\theta;Y_{\mid X}) = \sum log( \frac{\Gamma(\frac{m+1}{2})}{\sqrt{\pi m}\Gamma(\frac{m}{2})}(1+\frac{(y_{i} - x_{i}^{T}\beta)^2}{m})^{-\frac{m+1}{2}}) </math>
where we just used the definition of the density function of the t-distribution. (38) can be simplified to
<math> (39) \quad \mathcal{L}(\theta;Y_{\mid X}) = N[log(\Gamma(\frac{m+1}{2})) - log(\sqrt{\pi m}\Gamma(\frac{m}{2}))] -\frac{m+1}{2} \sum log(1+\frac{(y_{i} - x_{i}^{T}\beta)^2}{m}) </math>
so that (if we assume that the degrees of freedom ''m'' are known)
<math> (40) \quad \textit{argmax} \{ \mathcal{L}(\theta;Y_{\mid X}) \} = \textit{argmax} \{ -\frac{m+1}{2} \sum log(1+\frac{(y_{i} - x_{i}^{T}\beta)^2}{m}) \} = \textit{argmin} \{ \sum log(1+\frac{(y_{i} - x_{i}^{T}\beta)^2}{m}) \}. </math>
With the criterion function
<math> (41) \quad f(\beta_{1}, \beta_{2}) = \sum log(1+\frac{(y_{i} - \beta_{1} - \beta_{2}x_{i})^2}{m}) </math>
the methods above can readily applied to calculate the Maximum Likelihood Estimator <math>(\hat{\beta}_{1,ML}, \hat{\beta}_{2,ML})</math> maximizing (41).
== References ==
* Alt, W. (2002): "Nichtlineare Optimierung", Vieweg: Braunschweig/Wiesbaden * Härdle, W. and Simar, L. (2003): "Applied Multivariate Statistical Analysis", Springer: Berlin Heidelberg * Königsberger, K. (2004): "Analysis I", Springer: Berlin Heidelberg * Ruud, P. (2000): "Classical Econometric Theory", Oxford University Press: New York
{{AltBookCat}}

== Letter Frequency == Whenever you consider any available language, it gives information about the frequency of letters that occur most frequently in it. The same matter is more enough for cryptanalysis (process of discovering ciphertexts) which is more beneficial when encryption is performed using the Conventional Classical Encryption Techniques.
This gives statistical information of data that cryptanalysts can use in order to decrypt the encrypted data, provided the language in which data is present is known.
[[Category:Cryptography]]

In many ways the United Nations is a product of the Second World War. It took quite a bit of effort to forge the political alliances necessary to build the Allied military force that defeated the Axis powers during this war. Even before the formal surrender of Germany and Japan, it was realized that a long-term relationship should be developed among those countries that participated in the defeat of Facism, and a political solution that had global input needed to occur with the territories captured from the Axis powers.
During the final years of WWII, the name of the alliance had even changed, with the term United Nations being used formally for the first time as the name of the allied nations in press releases and newspaper accounts. While not formally the organization that exists today that is called the United Nations, many of the tasks that are now handled by the various Secretariats of the UN were first started at this time. There was also a strong sentiment among all of the participants of this alliance that they should not repeat the same mistakes that occurred at the end of the First World War, and in retrospect it could be argued that the framers of the United Nations have largely succeeded in that task.
Another aspect of the organization of the United Nations is the need to coordinate new participation in the war. The wartime alliance toward the end of WWII had many new countries willing to participate directly and indirectly in the combat operations, but this requried formal alliance treaties independently with each of the major allied powers and grew more complex as more countries joined the alliance. It was becoming so complex that some otherwise needed wartime supplies were actually refused because of the political bureaucracy that was developing.
Some international agencies such as the International Postal Union and the International Telecommunications Union pre-date the founding of the United Nations as well, but currently receive support from the UN and are considered appendenges to the larger organization as well and are governed under charters issued by the UN. There were also some aspects of the League of Nations that were absorbed into the United Nations, as most of the participants in the older League of Nations were also members of the United Nations as well. This is largely the result of a spirit of cooperation between nations that existed in the years prior to WWII, particularly for issues that didn't seem to have significant differences of opinion on how to proceed but required cooperation and standardization.
[[Category:United Nations]]

In Italian, ''passato prossimo'' is a very common tense expressing a recent, concluded action. To have an idea, you can use passato prossimo for an action you have just done, let's say from five minutes ago to two or three days ago. Despite this rule (which is not as strict as you can imagine), in northern Italy ''passato prossimo'' is also used to refer to actions which took place years ago, and the use of the correct tense for these cases, the ''passato remoto'', is almost disappeared (but its use is compulsory when writing). On the other hand, in southern Italy, the ''passato prossimo'' tense has been dropped, and, especially in Sicily, ''passato remoto'' is used in its stead.
just an example of conjugation:
'''fare''' (to do) ---- transitive verb, you must use "avere" to form the tense:
io ho fatto </br> tu hai fatto </br> egli ha fatto </br> noi abbiamo fatto </br> voi avete fatto </br> essi hanno fatto </br>
[[Category:Italian]]
[[es:Italiano/Passato prossimo]]

This ''Italic text'' tense is like the third form of the verbs in English (done, fallen...), and is used only to compose some other tenses like ''passato prossimo'', ''trapassato prossimo/remoto'', ''congiuntivo trapassato''.
A general rule to form the ''Participio passato'' (not valid for the irregular verbs) is the following
'''for the first and the third group (-''are'' and -''ire'' verbs)''':
-drop '''-re'''</br> -add '''-to'''
examples: dare (to give) = da'''''to''''', mangiare (to eat) = mangia'''''to''''', dormire (to sleep) = dormi'''''to'''''.
'''''for the second group (-''ere'' verbs)'''''</br> -drop '''-ere'''</br> -add '''-uto'''
cadere (to fall) = cad'''''uto'''''; avere (to have) = av'''''uto'''''</br> Remember that for the verbs in which ''-ere'' follows '''-sc''' (conoscere (to know)), the sound sh must be preserved also in the ''participio'' ''passato form'', so an -i must be added in front of -uto:
conoscere = conosc'''i'''''uto''
some irregular verbs:
essere (to be) = stato
[[Category:Italian]]
[[es:Italiano/Passato]]

The following demonstrates what's a state function and what's not a state function.
<math>q_{rev} \;</math> is not exact differential for a gas obeying van der Waals' equation, but <math>\frac{q_{rev}}{T}</math> is as demonstrated below:
<math>dq_{rev} \;=\left ( \frac{\partial U}{\partial T} \right )_vdT+\left [ P_{ext}+\left ( \frac{\partial U}{\partial V} \right )_T \right ]dV</math>
We assume quasistatic situation, so <math>P_{ext} = P \;</math>.
<math>dq_{rev} \;=\left ( \frac{\partial U}{\partial T} \right )_vdT+\left [ P+\left ( \frac{\partial U}{\partial V} \right )_T \right ]dV</math>
<math>=C_vdT+\left [ P+\left ( \frac{\partial U}{\partial V} \right )_T \right ]dV</math>
<math>=C_vdT+\left [ P+\left ( \frac{a}{\overline V^2} \right ) \right ]dV</math>
<math>=C_vdT+\left ( \frac{RT}{\overline V-b} \right )dV</math>
Now, you take the cross partial derivatives.
<math>\left ( \frac{\partial C_v}{\partial V} \right )_T=0</math>
<math>\left ( \frac{\partial \left ( \frac{RT}{\overline V-b} \right )}{\partial T} \right )_V=\frac{R}{\overline V-b}</math>
They are not equal; hence, <math>q_{rev} \;</math> is not exact differential (not a state function).
However, if we take <math>\frac{q_{rev}}{T}</math> it will be exact differential (a state function).
<math>\frac{dq_{rev}}{T}=\frac{C_v}{T}dT+\left ( \frac{R}{\overline V-b} \right )dV</math>
Take the cross partial derivatives.
<math>\left ( \frac{\partial \left ( \frac{C_v}{T}\right )}{\partial V} \right )_T=0</math>
<math>\left ( \frac{\partial \left ( \frac{R}{\overline V-b} \right )}{\partial T} \right )_V=0</math>
Both are equal making <math>\frac{q_{rev}}{T}</math> exact differential (a state function).
{{BookCat}}
[[fr:Chimie physique/Fonction d'état]]

Thank you very much for being here, --[[User:EuropracBHIT|EuropracBHIT]] 01:01, 19 January 2006 (UTC).-- {{Userpage}} == Your account will be renamed ==
Hello, The developer team at Wikimedia is making some changes to how accounts work, as part of our on-going efforts to provide new and better tools for our users like cross-wiki notifications. These changes will mean you have the same account name everywhere. This will let us give you new features that will help you edit and discuss better, and allow more flexible user permissions for tools. One of the side-effects of this is that user accounts will now have to be unique across all 900 Wikimedia wikis. See [[m:Special:MyLanguage/Single User Login finalisation announcement|the announcement]] for more information. Unfortunately, your account clashes with another account also called Paul.Paquette. To make sure that both of you can use all Wikimedia projects in future, we have reserved the name Paul.Paquette~enwikibooks that only you will have. If you like it, you don't have to do anything. If you do not like it, you can [[Special:GlobalRenameRequest|pick out a different name]]. Your account will still work as before, and you will be credited for all your edits made so far, but you will have to use the new account name when you log in. Sorry for the inconvenience. Yours,
[[m:User:Keegan (WMF)|Keegan Peterzell]]
Community Liaison, Wikimedia Foundation
